Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Developing n-type low bandgap conjugated macromolecules based on aza-dipyrromethene
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Genevieve Sauve of Case Western Reserve University will synthesize n-type, low bandgap conjugated macromolecules. The approach is to use aza-dipyrromethene (aza-DIPY) dyes as a comonomer building block, because aza-DIPYs are red-absorbers and have high electron affinities; their electronic properties also should be tunable via changes in substituents and chelation of metal ions. The aza-DIPY comonomers will be synthesized and used to preprare alternating copolymers with aryl-bis-alkynyl or aryl-bis-alkenyl units. The opto-electronic properties of the polymers will be determined, and then selected conjugated polymers will be integrated into polymer solar cells by blending them with electron-donating polymers such as poly(3-hexylthiophene). To direct nanoscale phase separation of the blend, poly(3-hexylthiophene) end-functionalized with aza-DIPY-based molecules will be synthesized and used as blending agents. Film morphologies will be analyzed and correlated with blend composition and device performance. The education plan and broader impacts of this program include: 1) implementing active-learning strategies in classroom and laboratory teaching assignments as well as incorporating solar energy conversion topics into the undergraduate and graduate curriculum; 2) mentoring and preparing undergraduate and graduate students to undertake cutting edge multidisciplinary research; and 3) serving as a role model and mentor for women students studying science and engineering.

Solar cells made from electrically conducting plastics are technologically promising but suffer from low conversion efficiencies and irreproducibility in processing. This research seeks to address some of those issues by enhancing our fundamental understanding of how to synthesize new organic polymers to capture light and efficiently turn it into electrical energy. The polymers might also find application in lightweight, flexible organic electronics and display technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic photovoltaics (OPVs) are a promising technology to convert sunlight into electricity. By using organic semiconductors instead of inorganic semiconductors, OPVs have the potential to be inexpensive, scalable, flexible, lightweight, and non-toxic. However, low power conversion efficiency has limited their commercialization. This research seeks to improve efficiency by designing the next generation of organic semiconductors. 

OPVs typically consist of a blend of two active materials: an electron donor, or p-type material, and an electron acceptor, or n-type material. Most of the past research had focused on optimizing the electron donor, while using a fullerene derivative as the electron acceptor. However, fullerene derivatives have many disadvantages that limit OPV performance. For example, they do not strongly absorb light in the visible range of the spectra, it is hard to tune their energy levels, and they are expensive to make. To overcome these limitations, we explored using aza-dipyrromethenes (ADP) as building blocks for alternative electron acceptors. ADPs were chosen because of their high absorption in the visible to near-IR region, their high electron affinities and ease of synthesis. Unlike most building blocks used in the design of organic semiconductors, ADPs are ligands that can coordinate with metal ions, thus adding another powerful way to tune their properties. 

The main goals of this research was to (i) synthesize and characterize conjugated macromolecules using ADP as building blocks, (ii) test the new compounds in OPVs, and (iii) optimize performance by directing nanoscale phase separation of the blends through molecular design of our electron acceptors. In the first part of the project, we focused on incorporating ADP into alternating conjugated polymers. We were able to make materials that strongly absorb light in the visible to near IR region of the spectra, up to ~1000 nm. We were also able to tune the properties of these low band-gap materials through chelation and side-chain modifications. However, when blended with the common electron donor poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT), low efficiencies were obtained due to unfavorable blend morphology. We first attempted to control morphology by end-functionalizing P3HT with ADP. However, this strategy turned out to be synthetically challenging. 

In the process, we discovered a better way to control blend morphology: instead of making conjugated polymers, we turned to homoleptic zinc complexes of ADP. In particular, we discovered that Zn(II) complex of ADP with  phenylethynyl groups at the pyrrolic positions (Zn(WS3)2) gave a large, 3D molecule with high absorption 600-800 nm, high electron affinity, low internal reorganization energy for electron transfer, and high efficiency in OPVs when paired with P3HT. The research showed that the non-planarity of these compounds enabled favorable blend morphology with P3HT due to a better balance between self-aggregation of each materials and miscibility of the two blend materials. We studied the structure-property relationships of these types of complexes and have learned about how to tune their properties. Collaborations were also initiated to better understand our systems. Our work is significant because it discovered new alternative organic semiconductors and helped establish design rules for alternative acceptors for solution-processable OPVs. 

Broader impacts include training of several graduate and undergraduate students to do cutting-edge research in a multidisciplinary and cooperative environment, preparing them for the workforce. It also facilitated mentoring several high school students, giving them an opportunity to discover science and encourage them to pursue a career in science or engineering. As a woman in science, I thrived to serve as a role model and mentor for women students interested in careers in science and engineering. 

Results of our studies have been disseminated through 16+ peer-reviewed journal articles, including a perspective and a personal account, as well as a book chapter, video and in multiple conferences and seminars.
